verses.verse: ((1 Job complaineth that he is contemned of the most contemptible,11, 21 because of his adversity and affliction.23 Death is the house of all flesh.) ) But now they that are younger than I, (That is, mine estate is changed, and whereas before the ancient men were glad to do me reverence, the young men now contemn me.) mock me: yea, they whose fathers I have refused to set with the (Meaning to be my shepherds, or to keep my dogs.) dogs of my flocks.
For whereto should the strength of their hands have served me, seeing age (That is, their fathers died for famine before they came to age.) perished in them?
For poverty and famine they were solitary, fleeing into the wilderness, which is dark, desolate and waste.
They cut up (Or, mallows.) nettles by the bushes, and the juniper roots was their meat.

They were (Job showeth that these that mocked him in his affliction, were like to their fathers, wicked and lewd fellows, such as he here describeth.) chased forth from among men: they shouted at them, as at a thief.
Therefore they dwelt in the clefts of rivers, in the holes of the earth and rocks.
They roared among the bushes, and under the thistles they gathered themselves.
They were the children of fools, and the children of villains, which were more vile than the earth.
And now am I their (They make songs of me, and mock at my misery.) song, and I am their talk.
They abhor me, and flee far from me, and spare not to spit in my face.

Because that God hath loosed my (God hath taken from me the force, credit, and authority wherewith I kept them in subjection.) cord and humbled me, (He said that the young men when they saw him, hid themselves, as Job 29:8, and now in his misery they were impudent and licentious.) they have loosed the bridle before me.
The youth rise up at my right hand: they have pushed my feet, and have trode on me as on the (That is, they sought by all means how they might destroy me.) paths of their destruction.
They have destroyed my paths: they took pleasure at my calamity, they had no (They need none to help them.) help.
They came as a great breach of waters, and (By my calamity they took an occasion against me.) under this calamity they come on heaps.
Fear is turned upon me: and they pursue my soul as the wind, and mine health passeth away as a cloud.
Therefore my soul is now (My life faileth me, and I am as half dead.) poured out upon me, and the days of affliction have taken hold on me.
(Meaning, sorrow.) It pierceth my bones in the night, and my sinews take no rest.
For the great vehemency is my garments changed, which compasseth me about, as the collar of my coat.
(That is, God hath brought me into contempt.) He hath cast me into the mire, and I am become like ashes and dust.
When I cry unto thee, thou dost not hear me, neither regardest me, when I stand up.

Thou turnest thyself (He speaketh not thus to accuse God, but to declare the vehemency of his affliction, whereby he was carried beside himself.) cruelly against me, and art enemy unto me with the strength of thine hand.
Thou takest me up and causest me to ride upon the (He compareth his afflictions to a tempest or whirlwind.) wind, and makest my (Or, wisdom, or law.) strength to fail.
Surely I know that thou wilt bring me to death, and to the house appointed for all the living.
Doubtless none can stretch his hand (None can deliver me thence, though they lament at my death.) unto the grave, though they cry in his destruction.
Did not I weep with him that was in trouble? was not my soul in heaviness for the poor?
Yet when I looked for good, (Instead of comforting they mocked at me.) evil came unto me: and when I waited for light, there came darkness.
My bowels did boil without rest: for the days of affliction are come upon me.

I went mourning (Not delighting in any worldly thing, no not so much as in the use of the Sun.) without sun: I stood up in the Congregation (Lamenting them that were in affliction, and moving others to pity them.) and cried.
I am a brother to the (I am like the wild beasts that desire most solitary places.) Dragons, and a companion to the Ostriches.
My skin is black upon me, and my bones are burnt with (With the heat of affliction.) heat.
Therefore mine harp is turned to mourning, and mine organs into the voice of them that weep.
